data.title: Conflict: a Distributed Condition: Contemporary War Ecologies
data.desc:
Conflict is not an exception or an isolated event — it is a constant condition running through society. It is not limited to war or explicit clashes: it emerges within collective life as friction, as a continuous confrontation between competing needs, systems, and visions.
It is not a punctual episode but a latent and distributed condition. It takes on asymmetric, often invisible forms, embedded in cultural practices, social relations, and infrastructures. Its logic is not confined to violence: it also structures coexistence, shaping who holds privilege and who is pushed to the margins.
Exploring distributed conflicts means reading the present as a field where techniques of offense multiply and blur into the infrastructures society depends on. The goal is to generate critical devices, scenarios, and questions that probe the ambiguous nature of conflict as a diffuse condition in a post-territorial age.

data.title: Cognitive Dissonance
data.desc: It's a universal psychological mechanism: we all experience small conflicts between thoughts, values, and actions every day. It explains a person's choices and behaviors, attitudes that can sometimes even seem irrational. It shows that we don't always make logical decisions: we choose solutions that reduce psychological distress, even at the expense of objective coherence. This explains phenomena such as polarization, fake news, and personal justifications.

data.title: Neuropolitics
data.desc: Neuroscience, AI, and politics are at the center of contemporary debate. It's a hot and plausible topic. It implies a strong cognitive conflict: more knowledge and transparency on the one hand, more surveillance and manipulation on the other. It opens the door to tangible devices (bracelets, helmets, pills, algorithms), which can be prototyped in credible but also disturbing ways. Politics affects everyone, and a project that questions freedom of thought and voting generates immediate discussion.

data.title: Learning
data.desc:
The learning phase is crucial for cognitive development and conflict: Children actively construct their cognitive schemas; it is during this phase that lasting ways of dealing with dissonance are defined.
Exposing children to cognitive discrepancies creates a state of imbalance that pushes them toward accommodating new schemas. 
Working in groups with different ideas exposes children to their first meaningful experiences of cognitive disagreement. These differences influence whether conflict is productive or counterproductive.
Parents transmit values, explanations, and strategies (explicit and implicit) that shape how children deal with dissonance.

data.title: Cognitive Hedonia
data.desc:
Mark Fisher coined the term "depressive hedonia" to describe a modern paradox: people who obsessively seek pleasure but never get real satisfaction from it.
Constant stimulation from the digital world overactivates our "wanting" system (dopamine) but makes our "pleasure" system (opioids) less sensitive. Result: we keep seeking rewards but never feel truly satisfied.
The mental conflict is frustrating: people understand that scrolling social media or consuming endless entertainment is pointless, but they can't stop. Fisher calls this "powerless reflexivity" - you know what you should do but remain trapped in behaviors that harm you.
This is a specific consequence of late capitalism that has created an environment of constant stimulation never seen before in human history, where seeking gratification becomes compulsive but never satisfying.

data.title: Hypnosis
data.desc: Hypnosis shows that our thinking isn't as stable as we think. When hypnotized, people accept ideas they would normally reject. This lets us create mental conflicts in a controlled way to see how the mind deals with them. Surprisingly, these conflicts can actually help people change in ways that wouldn't be possible otherwise. But this makes us wonder: if suggestions can so easily get past our logical thinking, how much control do we really have over our daily decisions?

data.title: Devil shift
data.desc:
The devil shift reflects a universal bias: we tend to see opponents as more hostile, threatening, and powerful than they really are, seeking evidence to confirm this view while ignoring anything that challenges it.
The angel shift is the opposite bias: we idealize allies, seeing them as more virtuous, trustworthy, and capable than they actually are, while overlooking their flaws or mistakes.

data.title: Cognitive overload
data.desc:
It has been established that as cognitive overload increases, so does the feeling of anxiety and avoidance when it comes to making decisions. This can trigger decision fatigue.
The quality of decisions deteriorates as cognitive resources are depleted; ultimately, this leads to outright decision avoidance or a tendency to delegate choices, even important ones. When the amount of information exceeds the threshold of available cognitive resources, they begin to compete with each other.

data.title: First review
data.desc:
The review examined the concepts of decision fatigue, devil shift, and depressive hedonia, highlighting their relevance to psychological and perceptual processes. Particular attention was given to the role of intrapsychic mechanisms in facilitating empathy, with cognitive dissonance identified as a valuable framework for interpreting marketing strategies.
Methodologically, the systematic use of “what if” questions was recommended to explore potential scenarios and their implications. 
In the construction of mood boards, the inclusion of real-world elements—such as tools, materials, and abstract signs—was emphasized as a means of eliciting and representing core aspects of the investigated concept.
Conflict includes organized and perceived violence, and prototypes must feel real rather than exist materially.

data.title: Devil shift and cancel culture
data.desc:
Applying the devil shift to an individual means concentrating all blame on them, reducing complexity to a single perspective. The person becomes the “absolute villain,” even if not necessarily so.
With social media, this dynamic intensifies: a single case can trigger collective judgment, often fuelled by past episodes or statements, even if now irrelevant.
Rarely do we ask whether we too might have acted like the “cancelled” person. Group pressure reduces critical capacity, fostering conformity and flattening judgment.
Those targeted are labelled and marginalised, raising questions about inclusion and social responsibility: are we truly as free from prejudice as we believe?
The project encourages seeing things from the perspective of the cancelled person, building empathy and breaking down stigmatisation, so their complexity and humanity are not reduced to a single label.

data.title: Cognitive Hedonia
data.desc:
We use social media because it gives us pleasure and releases dopamine. On one hand, we know we’re wasting time and engaging in a fleeting search for gratification, yet we can’t seem to disconnect. This mechanism resembles an addictive pattern.
In this context, we could imagine a kind of “drug” that provides exactly what we’re seeking—the immediate pleasure and dopamine release. That way, we wouldn’t need to spend time on social media to entertain ourselves, because our brains have already received what they want. But would it truly be satisfying?
This approach could free up the time we usually feel we lack to do what we really want. And if we do have that free time, will we actually use it as we intend?

data.title: Decision fatigue and vote
data.desc:
In a world where voter interest is declining and turnout is at historic lows, who has truly shaped the system we live in—those who voted, or those who abstained?
Abstaining and leaving decisions to the majority can be a symptom of decision fatigue. People are often unmotivated to inform themselves, showing little interest—even though the outcomes affect them on multiple levels.
This creates a cognitive conflict: political choices are complex, ambiguous, and full of imperfect alternatives. The inability to decide without discomfort leads to the simplest solution: not deciding at all. Abstention thus acts as a strategy to reduce cognitive noise.
But who really decided our system—the voters or the abstainers? And what if the tools meant to guide our choices—polls, surveys, tests—actually alienate us, flattening our critical and civic engagement?
Non-choice is, in fact, a choice. Even if we believe that abstaining carries no consequences, it does—and it impacts both the system and those who abstain.

data.title: Cognitive Hedonia 2
data.desc:
In a world that no longer offers stable pleasure or gratification from traditional sources of entertainment, the individual experiences a profound cognitive conflict: to feel authentic sensations, they turn to content that, rationally, should provoke repulsion—true crime, violent news, gore. The mind is thus forced to reconcile two irreconcilable poles: the pleasure derived from intense emotional stimulation and the moral awareness that this pleasure stems from the suffering of others.
It becomes imperative to show how the need to “feel something” is captured and exploited by the market of pain, prompting the audience to reflect on the human and ethical cost of turning others’ suffering into entertainment.

data.title: Second review
data.desc:
Reflect: What conflicts does this theme create?
What issues does it cause in today’s society? Provide concrete examples.
Project Concept:
What kind of project could emerge from a theme like this? Think about the message you want to convey concretely through the project.
Moodboard:
Translate the concept into visuals through examples (e.g., images of Trump, Netflix).

data.title: Third review
data.desc: The general themes are solid, fertile, and interesting, but the theme of voting doesn’t fit well with the concept of decision fatigue, since voter abstention stems more from lack of interest than from too many choices. The “what if” questions are too generic and should be made more specific. In the moodboard, some images are too abstract and don’t clearly relate to the theme, while the ones showing concrete cases or the organizations chosen for the scenario work better. It’s recommended to introduce a small initial change that leads to a more distant and engaging scenario.

data.title: Case study 1 - Devil shift
data.desc: People tend to avoid cognitive dissonance, which is the discomfort that arises when new facts or ideas conflict with their existing beliefs. Even in the face of objective evidence and data, people often prefer to ignore or rationalize information that challenges their beliefs rather than change their minds. This psychological mechanism makes it difficult to alter opinions and explains why facts alone rarely suffice to change deeply held beliefs.
links: Do facts have the power to change our minds?

data.title: Case study 1 - Decision fatigue
data.desc: The study by Danziger et al. (2011) analyzed over 1,100 parole decisions made by Israeli judges over 10 months, finding that decisions varied greatly depending on the time of day. At the beginning of sessions, about 65% of requests were granted, but the percentage dropped to almost zero before breaks and rose again after meals.  This phenomenon was attributed to decision fatigue: when judges were mentally exhausted, they tended to choose the simplest and most conservative option—denying parole

data.title: Case study 1 - depressive hedonia
data.desc: The case study examines how habitual exposure to violent media contributes to emotional desensitization.  Findings indicate that individuals with higher exposure to violent media exhibit reduced physiological arousal (as measured by skin conductance level) and lower anxiety when viewing violent scenes, yet report greater pleasure and show faster activation of aggressive thoughts.  This desensitization effect appears to be specific to violent content and is not observed in response to sad or humorous scenes.

data.title: Case study 2 - Devil shift
data.desc: The “Devil Shift” in political science describes how, in intense conflicts, actors tend to see opponents as more powerful and malevolent than they are. It involves attributing negative motives, judging behavior harshly, overestimating opponents’ influence, and underestimating one’s own. Greater ideological distance amplifies this effect, which reinforces conflicts and hinders cooperation.

The study, based on nine cases in Switzerland, shows that the Devil Shift is stronger among interest groups, political parties, and powerful actors compared to state officials or weaker actors. Additionally, the Devil Shift is more pronounced in processes involving socio-economic issues. The data confirm that the perceived “malevolence” dimension is more widespread than the perceived power dimension.

data.title: Case study 2 - depressive hedonia
data.desc: In recent years, true crime has become a mass phenomenon across series, podcasts, and social media. However, behind the fascination with real crime lies a risk: overexposure to violent content can increase anxiety, paranoia, and stress—especially among young people, who struggle to maintain emotional distance.  Experts warn that while watching true crime is not inherently harmful, excessive consumption can distort one’s perception of reality and personal safety.

data.title: Case study 3 - depressive hedonia
data.desc: The study examines how exposure to violent media influences individual and collective psychology regarding crime and aggression. Repeated exposure can lead to emotional desensitization, greater acceptance of aggression, reduced empathy for victims, and a distorted view of violence as normal or acceptable. It also emphasizes the media’s role in shaping public perceptions of justice, policy responses, and social attitudes toward violence.

data.title: case study 4 - depressive hedonia
data.desc: It analyzes the boom of the true crime genre between 2018 and 2019, attributed both to the desire for strong emotions and morbid curiosity, and to the need to understand the darker side of human nature and society.  The ethical dilemma of voyeurism and the sensationalization of suffering is also discussed.

data.desc: Repeated exposure to negative news can lead to emotional desensitization, reduced empathy, and weaker moral judgments—a phenomenon known as the “moral repetition effect.” Doomscrolling worsens this effect, potentially causing apathy, emotional fatigue, and lower motivation to address injustices. Mindful media use, critical thinking, and digital breaks can help preserve moral sensitivity.

data.title: Case study 2 - decision fatigue
data.desc: Case study on judges, scientific journal editors, students, and healthcare professionals.  The study highlights how decision fatigue leads to more impulsive choices, reliance on cognitive shortcuts, and poorer performance—especially under conditions of stress, complexity, or repetitive decision-making.

Somatic Marker Hypothesis (Damasio)  Summary: Damasio proposed that “somatic markers” (bodily sensations linked to emotions) help narrow down and evaluate options in complex decisions—a mechanism through which emotion facilitates quick and adaptive decision-making. This theory has been supported by neuropsychological and neuroimaging studies, but it has also been discussed and criticized. Nonetheless, it remains one of the most influential frameworks connecting emotion and choice.

data.title: Fourth Review
data.desc:
We should propose something that emphasizes the conflict — something that clearly defines the type of subject, the context, and the dynamics at play. The cognitive bias of the devil shift tends to fade away, but it needs to be brought back into focus. How do we imagine this as a staging?
The reduction of conflict already leads us into a scenario filled with too many “what ifs.”

data.title: Panopticon
data.desc:
In the age of mass surveillance and commodified data, we are all constantly watched.
Our devices, online presence, and even physical movements have become assets owned by corporations and governments—a digital panopticon without consent or awareness.

The machine’s invisible gaze monitors and disciplines us, turning Internet users into lifelong prisoners.
At once observer and observed, we inhabit a state of alienation—half human, half data.
A warning about how invisible control has become, and how numb we are to the loss of our privacy.

data.title: Fifth review
data.desc:
Hedonia: the project currently relies too heavily on the idea of “simulation,” which risks diluting the real intensity of the experience.
What truly matters is designing a situation where the user is genuinely and emotionally involved.
We should focus on how the conflict is activated and felt, rather than on constructing a complex device or system. The experience itself — how it unfolds and engages the participant — is what gives the project meaning.

The concept of the devil shift must be reframed as a cognitive conflict: who silences whom, and for what reason?
This shift helps us return to the human level of perception and agency.
The project’s strength lies in its storytelling — the ability to create resonance through familiar contexts, subtle narratives, and everyday situations that feel real but are carefully constructed.

The guiding principle is simplicity.
The experience should not be overcomplicated with layers of simulation or political overtones, but rather aim to provoke reflection and awareness through clarity, tension, and emotional engagement.

data.title: Sixth review
data.desc:
The goal is to follow a clear, logical process to understand how emotional security can be built and sustained.
At this stage, the focus should be on completely removing cognitive conflict, emphasizing instead the mechanisms that help prevent it.

It’s important not to get fixated on the idea of “silencing”, so as not to restrict the conceptual space or creative possibilities.
The guiding question becomes: what forms of emotional security can be activated to prevent or neutralize cognitive conflict?
From here, we can imagine a device — physical or conceptual — designed to protect and resolve conflict, creating a sense of stability and reassurance.
In parallel, it’s essential to define the brand’s visual and conceptual identity: researching companies or case studies that either perform similar actions or embody a tone of voice consistent with the type of communication we envision.

data.title: Cognitive security
data.desc:
What if we shifted the focus from silencing others to silencing our own thoughts?
When we perceive a trigger — through a certain frequency or noise — the thought could be blocked, not replaced, effectively stopping cognitive conflict before it arises.
This action would leave space for reflection: is it a protective mechanism, or a subtle form of self-censorship? The ambiguity remains open.
Keywords: Trigger, Overstimulation, Sound frequencies, Emptiness, Detachment, Isolation, Protection of one's thoughts, Shutdown / freeze, Linearity

data.title: Review
data.desc:
The project explores how silencing can itself become a form of cognitive dissonance — or how a system might transform silence into dissonance rather than eliminating it.
The aim is to reverse the idea of cognitive dissonance, treating it not as a cause but as a result of conflict, shifting the focus from the personal to the collective level.

Through conceptual exercises like Crazy 8, the work imagines objects or devices that create playful tensions between silence and perception — an experience of “Cognitive Cancelling”, a kind of cognitive deprivation that transforms messages instead of erasing them.
At the core lies a simple idea: every conflict stems from a distortion of reality — an emotional bias that triggers discomfort.
The challenge is to design a tone of voice, message, and communicative mechanism that can reveal this inner distortion.

data.title: Cognitive security review
data.desc:
The project explores the idea of “switching off our thoughts”, using everyday behaviors like scrolling Instagram as a metaphor for cognitive disengagement.
It combines concepts such as spatial audio, meditation apps like Headspace, and devices that distort perception, to create an experiential scenario where users reflect on their inner dynamics.

The focus is on building a specific scenario from a “what if”, which defines both the product and the project’s identity. Storytelling is key, with metaphors like natural filters (mussels or clams) illustrating the concept of filtering or controlling thoughts.

Ultimately, the scenario and narrative serve to define the branding and purpose: why would users want to turn off their thoughts, and what does the project reveal about human perception and behavior?

data.title: Social isolation, socio-cultural role of seashells and sound
data.desc: Expansion on the research needed to make the narrative context more grounded and based on actual findings, linking both visual metaphors and means to effectively communicate the concept through a measurable output.

data.title: Reversal to Literal helmet shape
data.desc: The decision has been made to revert to a more literal and provocative form, with the strategic goal of decisively emphasizing the idea of a protective shell or armor. This necessitates initiating a second attempt at developing the shell-inspired helmet concept.

data.title: Pointer output integration
data.desc: The Pointer device is conceived as a portable sensor designed to detect potential detrimental triggers from another individual when directed at them. To signal potential danger, the device emits a sound or illuminates. The prescribed protective response involves the user donning the helmet, thereby distancing themselves from the resulting discomfort and potential negative thoughts. The Pointer could be implemented either as a wearable item or as a small accessory, such as a keychain.

data.title: First branding review
data.desc: The proposed company name lacks sufficient provocation. Currently, the Sony-related references are most relevant visual-wise. The aesthetic requires a shift toward being less gentle to better convey an optimistic technological outlook that prioritizes functional emergence over other concerns. It's advisable to avoid the issue of comparative messaging altogether, rather than adopting a 'caring against noise' approach that risks conflating with genuine positive or wellbeing narratives. Furthermore, an excessive focus on the sea motif may inadvertently lead the brand discourse toward themes of sustainability. The graphic aspects of Sony's communication are highly effective in conveying their message and should be utilized as a direct source of inspiration and adaptation. Crucially, the core message regarding the discomfort of comparison must not be overlooked; the brand should clearly communicate that comparison is to be avoided. It is time to initiate the development of the technical component of the product narrative.

data.title: Dreamlike visual identity
data.desc: The brand identity has transitioned towards new visual concepts that are significantly more dreamlike and less explicitly organic. The new aesthetic draws heavily from the graphical rigor of Sony and the distinctive patina of the Y2K era—a direction reflected across the updated color palettes and overall look and feel. This strategic shift is justified because, unlike the previous organic and shell-inspired themes, the Y2K-infused, technological aesthetic possesses the necessary assertiveness and synthetic confidence required to communicate the core disruptive message effectively. The new approach avoids the passive connotations of natural materials, instead offering a visually precise and technologically optimistic framework that aligns with the brand's function as an active agent of controlled isolation.

data.title: Brand identities
data.desc:
New moodboards defining the updated aesthetic direction have been completed. The first moodboard draws direct inspiration from dreamlike Y2K aesthetics and technological optimism. It is characterized by the use of blue and orange color palettes, incorporating typical era distortion effects alongside a very simple typography. The second moodboard, conversely, draws inspiration from Japanese culture, emphasizing materials such as paper, embossing, and transparency. In this concept, the shell motif is utilized solely as an internal, non-explicit structure.
Concurrently, initial functional development has progressed with the first stages of Arduino programming.

data.title: Presentation output review
data.desc:
The connotative approach requires increased provocation, drawing inspiration from examples such as the Zimoun kinetic headphone installation or the work of Ugo La Pietra.

The brand narrative must be corrected from the outset: if the product is a wearable, the brand should enter the market by proposing a kind of technological "amulet" or "jewel" designed for self-protection.

If the product is a helmet, it must be intensely provocative and possess strong communicative power due to its physical dimension.

If the product is lighter (a jewel), careful consideration must be given to managing every component (e.g., routing cables through transparent tubing).

Material Considerations: Material choices should be evaluated (e.g., non-rigid, 3D-printed jewelry as seen in the work of Monica Castiglioni).

A critical decision must be made: selecting the path based on whether the aesthetic is fundamentally organic or decisively technological. Working on the brand identity will follow this decision.

data.title: Shell-helmet output feedback
data.desc: The product focus shifts to a wearable managed by an app. Bone conductors are suggested for cost/form factor. The key narrative is the Proximity Sensor: it creates a "personal bubble" that triggers noise when invaded (frontally detected), demonizing physical and mental confrontation. Durability and versatility remain vital. The object should be hollow, potentially shoulder-mounted for adaptability. The core message mustn't be lost

data.title: New metallic pattern ouput design
data.desc: The central concept chosen is protection, emphasizing an armor for the mind. The output form has been simplified to a headband housing the necessary components for the bone transducers, which generate a relaxing sound intended to suppress intrusive thoughts. The decoration features a metallic, slightly organic pattern that references both the shape of the brain and the Turing pattern. All internal components are rendered visible through a semi-opaque casing.

data.title: Recentering identity on the cognitive field
data.desc: New visual identity concepts are centered on the visual representation of complex phenomena, specifically utilizing reaction-diffusion principles (such as the Turing pattern) to symbolize the brain's internal structure and controlled chaos. Furthermore, the identity integrates both the physics of sound transmission and the visual manifestation of the product's effect on the surrounding environment, thereby externalizing the intended social and psychological boundary created by the device.

data.title: New cognitive visual elements
data.desc: New brand marks inspired by the brain and Turing patterns shift the visual identity toward cognitive science and soundwave aesthetics. This move led to removing the Japanese identity and the complex company backstory, streamlining the narrative to focus on the core technology of controlled isolation. The goal is clearer, more universal, and clinically neutral communication. The new poster campaign amplifies a disruptive, unsettling tone through themes of discomfort, eerie visuals, and avoidance-related idioms, using paper and metallic textures contrasted with smooth glass or transparency.

data.title: Provocative communication and output review
data.desc:
The communication needs shorter, sharper phrasing; the current messaging is too long. Typography should be cleaner and lighter, and the symbol requires more coherent curves and stroke consistency—its overlapping-circle motif should be thinner. The logotype’s detailed curve points make it unnecessarily heavy. A more fitting name would reference protection, such as “Armor.”
The concept is not yet provocative enough. Provocation should come either from the product’s form or its function, creating an unexpected or unsettling effect. The product should intentionally introduce a secondary problem—for example, a sound feature that is disruptive or induces discomfort. This built-in provocation must be part of the design. The idea should be examined through the lens of extreme interventions, such as lobotomy, historically used to suppress unwanted thoughts.

data.title: Same shape different effect output hypothesis
data.desc: Following the review, efforts were concentrated on enhancing the product's provocation without implementing substantial changes to the form factor, given the advanced stage of development. The strategic focus was therefore shifted entirely to the sound output. This function is now intended to provoke literal cognitive dissonance, achieved either through triggering the "polar bear effect" (attempted thought suppression leading to obsession) or by actively implanting false, calming memories into the user's experience.

data.title: Hypotesis on more provocative visual direction
data.desc: The observed general difficulty in effectively synthesizing all competing elements into a cohesive output persists. A potential strategic shift involves adopting a more radical and direct communication style, embracing a deliberately "crazier" aesthetic. This would necessitate seeking out new, highly provocative subjects for poster campaigns, potentially drawing inspiration from the imagery of social distancing enforced during the COVID-19 pandemic. Concurrently, efforts would focus on developing new payoffs and copy, exploring fresh subject matter, and refining the typography to align with this more assertive and disruptive direction.

data.title: Structural Failure and Mandatory Project Relaunch
data.desc: A state of general conceptual dissonance has been identified, indicating that the various project components no longer align. It is evident that an effective strategic direction for both product development and communication is currently unattainable, confirming a structural problem that necessitates a complete restart of the process. While isolation emerged incidentally, it is recognized as the most concrete manifestation of the central conflict and must therefore be rendered the core theme. Crucially, the current framework lacks a truly compelling and interesting critical key insight to drive the narrative forward.

data.title: Isolation as Synthetic Progress
data.desc: Isolation is conceptualized not merely as a temporary resolution to conflict, but as a natural evolutionary progression of the human mind adapting to a contemporary society characterized by increasing individualism and self-reference. Within this new paradigm, the mind can only achieve optimal prosperity and development when completely autonomous and distanced from others. This state is defined by the Eden metaphor: a perfectly secluded, self-contained environment that evolves solely upon itself, representing the apex of pleasure and beatitude. This absolute state of perfection, the text implies, is inevitably corrupted and lost the moment contact is established with the external world.

data.title: The visual logic of the new scenario
data.desc:
The visual language now aligns closely with biotech (e.g., Neuralink). The helmet functions as a training device, conditioning users to feel discomfort near others. The identity emphasizes radical simplification, coldness, and logical, technology-driven improvement.
Transparency and opacity symbolize integration and control over the mind. The aesthetic features metallic textures, cold tones, and brain/machine imagery. Posters use Swiss Style to present isolation as a logical human evolution, while blur and soft focus represent the helmet’s barrier. The color palette remains neutral.

data.title: New concept review
data.desc:
The scenarios and “what if” concepts work well and should be distilled for maximum impact. Communication must be visually compelling, emphasizing cognitive conflict from social interactions that drive isolation. Key product ideas include total environmental shielding, temple-squeezing cues, and material contrasts (opacity = chaos, transparency = solitude).
Messaging should create false pleasure—slightly warm but not soft. Communication artifacts (fake sub-products, home items, collaborations) can extend the brand narrative. The brand may operate solely online, with the slogan “better alone than in bad company” capturing its philosophy.

data.title: Integral helmet output
data.desc: The final strategic decision aligns with the repeatedly emphasized insight: that provocation emerges primarily from the form factor itself. The chosen output is a large, cumbersome, almost childish full-face helmet that instantly communicates the project's core concept of isolation. This transparent helmet incorporates both the sound functionality and the switchable opacity film, creating a dual output for both the wearer and their surroundings. Crucially, the product is redefined as a training device intended to use sound and conditioned reflexes to teach the consumer to maintain distance from others.

data.title: Monochromatic and blurry visual identity
data.desc: Initial trials with new color palettes proved unsuccessful. The final visual identity will therefore be refined based on the successful concepts of disturbance, glass effects, opacity, and blur. The aesthetic will rely on neutral color palettes and the inclusion of human subjects.

data.title: Material evaluation
data.desc:
During the initial production assessment for the full-face helmet with shoulder support, a key evaluation focused on the primary fabrication method: 3D printing versus thermoforming. Planning for the procurement of electronic components was initiated concurrently.

Before the final material selection was made, the first stage of physical development involved creating the full-face helmet prototype via 3D modeling with the required shoulder support. Pros and cons for each manufacturing method were rigorously weighed:

Thermoforming was considered for its potential to produce large, transparent, and uniform shells efficiently, but it was noted to lack the capacity for highly complex geometries.

3D printing offered superior design complexity, quicker iteration, and easier integration of internal fixtures, but presented challenges regarding the final surface finish, the difficulty of achieving perfect transparency on a large scale, and the potential for increased material costs for a structure of that size.

data.title: First successful tests
data.desc: Initial tests conducted on the sensors proved successful, validating their intended function. Concurrently, the preliminary posters have been validated as effective communication tools, and the desired sound functionality has been successfully implemented.

data.title: Typographic and detail rework
data.desc: Various refinements have been implemented across the brand identity, including final adjustments to the typography and enhanced overall characterization. Initial proposals for the logo animation and the teaser campaign have been completed and presented. The project has mostly received approval.

data.title: New visual identity applications
data.desc: Final assets, including the social media content, packaging design, and a series of new promotional posters, have been completed. These efforts culminated in the comprehensive systematization of the global visual identity, which now operates under a unified aesthetic. This finalized identity is characterized by a look that is simultaneously rigorous and direct, maintaining an aseptic quality in its presentation. This rigorous framework is utilized to focus attention squarely on the potential for human improvement and technological enhancement, positioning the brand as a precise and clinical means toward self-optimization and controlled betterment.

data.title: Preliminary prototyping review
data.desc: For E-den, the design requires a more coherent characterization linked to the brain. In addition to the bone transducers, other protrusions could be incorporated to secure the helmet. The objective is to bring forward proposals for physical development: specifically, utilizing rods/spikes as elements that can also evoke the concept of isolation. Further refinement proposals for the Armor brand mark should be prepared, while the E-den mark can remain as is. Detailed microscopic parameters can be distributed across the visual field

data.title: Teaser video concept and filming
data.desc: The realization of the teaser required two separate phases of filming. The campaign is built upon a very simple concept: the demonstration of the product's core functionality. Crucially, the teaser effectively communicates that maintaining distance from others represents the optimal and most functional state for the user.

data.title: Simplified output design review
data.desc: The product form should be simplified to the maximum extent, reduced to a cylinder. The current functionality—encompassing both sound and film elements—is now satisfactory. The priority must shift immediately to developing physical prototypes and commencing the tangible construction phase. Minor adjustments are required for the brand identity, particularly regarding the company mark, which needs greater expressiveness. The newly developed Armor brand mark is effective as it successfully conveys the product's core concepts.

data.title: Material decision
data.desc: Following a consultation on materials, the decision was made to utilize a Plexiglass tube for the main body. This material provides the required balance of lightness and rigidity while, crucially, delivering a perfectly transparent finish that would have been difficult to achieve using thermoforming or 3D printing. For the remaining structural components, 3D printing was selected due to its inherent lightness and ease of coloration.

data.title: Functional code and circuit
data.desc: The prototyped code and circuit have been finalized and are confirmed to be fully functional. Sound tests have been replaced with LED lights to try different levels and their respective functionality.

data.title: Mobile app ouput decision
data.desc: The current strategy necessitates focusing on a singular product offering, potentially an application, to achieve maximum narrative efficacy through output simplification. It is a critical requirement that the selected product must integrate a mechanism to return a meaningful experience or reflective feedback to the user. A mobile application was ultimately the preferred choice.

data.title: Organic brand identity concept
data.desc: Initial hypotheses for a possible branding direction draw inspiration from the sea, specifically the shell, which acts as an organism that clears the water. This serves as a metaphor for the product's function in clarifying and protecting the mind. The preliminary concepts for the brandmark are significantly influenced by Japanese tech brands, aiming to merge an organic yet professional aesthetic. The identity integrates further synthetic elements to achieve the desired look and feel, including metal, transparency, and paper embossing.

data.title: Earcuff output ideas
data.desc: Initial sketches feature an output that combines the referenced organic shapes with the concept of shells, specifically those through which one might hear calming sounds, replicating the experience of actual seashells. The proposed form would take the shape of a metallic earcuff.

data.title: First branding proposal
data.desc: First sea-inspired proposal of brand identity for a product named "Mamoru".

data.title: Second brand identity conceptualisation
data.desc: A second brand identity proposal has been developed. While retaining the sea and organic structures as foundational elements, a new visual component, 'blur,' was introduced. This element is intended to signify a barrier between the internal and external environments, conveying a sense of unreachability.

data.title: Branding proposal
data.desc: Blur and algae inspired second brand identity, naming and communication proposal.

data.title: E-den visual identity
data.desc:
The first visual identity draws from a dreamlike Y2K aesthetic: blue and cyan tones with orange accents, distortion and blur effects, and bright, futuristic environments. Simple, linear typography contrasts with the visual complexity. Transparent surfaces, plastic textures, and early-tech product references reinforce the idea of a personal technology that feels ethereal and beyond the physical.
The e-den identity, by contrast, conveys a controlled, aseptic technological optimism. Its name and payoff evoke a protected digital “paradise.” The rounded, lowercase logotype suggests accessible modernity. The campaign uses bright, airy settings and high-fidelity photography with subtle digital blurring. Its core messaging positions the product as a necessary, preemptive shield—both a defense against external threats and a tool for internal optimization.

data.title: Sheru visual identity
data.desc:
The second identity uses a clinical, highly structured aesthetic, blending biological fragility (shell forms, exposed mechanisms) with engineered precision. A minimal palette of whites, greys, and blacks, with subtle purple accents, supports a refined, architectural look. Textures like embossing, fine fractures, and etched patterns emphasize transparency and internal structure, conveying protection through design rather than decoration.
The SHERU identity builds on the idea of biological–technological armor. Its name and visuals evoke a shell, reinforced by a layered, protective logo. The campaign uses high contrast, slightly aged textures, and the Nautilus spiral to symbolize inner refuge. Messages stress isolation as safety, positioning SHERU as essential psychological and technological protection.

data.title: Failure of Organic Aesthetic
data.desc: The visually organic and marine-related aesthetic proved ultimately unsuccessful due to its inherent limitations in communicating the intended brand message. The gentle and fluid imagery associated with the sea unintentionally steered the identity toward generalized concepts of sustainability and wellbeing, which risked conflating the product with unrelated narratives. Crucially, this soft visual direction failed to integrate the essential elements of technological optimism and the required sense of provocation. The aesthetic was deemed too passive and accommodating, lacking the necessary functional rigor and psychological edge required to effectively represent the product's core purpose: establishing a firm boundary against external comparison and discomfort. The visual language, therefore, did not support the required confidence and assertive functionality of the technology.

data.title: Second shell-helmet output design
data.desc: The new helmet concept incorporates a metallic, tactile pattern intended to disguise the internal Arduino components. A key feature is a front-facing film over the eyes that possesses an opacity control and can be rendered opaque. In comparison to the earcuff concept, this device features visual signaling for communication with external parties and is designed for activation via biological stress signals. Furthermore, the helmet offers the possibility of becoming non-removable for a defined period of time. The overall form of the helmet will be strongly inspired by the shape of the shell.

data.title: Earcuff output review
data.desc: The product currently lacks an element of provocation. While aesthetically pleasing, the object fails to effectively communicate its core concept: isolation and the avoidance of comparison-induced discomfort. Consideration should be given to making the object more provocative in its form, or perhaps changing the product direction entirely. When developing the product, it is essential to consider the entire communication apparatus on a larger scale, where the physical product is merely one component of the overall experience. A key challenge for a wearable item is ensuring durability and versatility for use across multiple individuals. Small items present technical difficulties, overly large items incur high costs, making a mid-range size the optimal solution.

data.title: Earcuff: Functional and Narrative Deficiencies
data.desc: The proposed earcuff was ultimately considered ineffective as a product expression because it failed to adequately embody the brand's core concept of provocation and functional isolation. Although the form attempted to combine organic shapes with the sensory concept of the shell—suggesting calming sounds—the design itself did not visually communicate the intended message of disruption or the necessary technological confidence. Furthermore, as a wearable object, the earcuff introduced significant constraints related to durability and versatility for use by a diverse user base, which are critical considerations for any product developed at scale. The physical object, therefore, did not carry the required communicative weight and was seen as a passive element within the larger experience.

data.title: Interface output integration
data.desc: The product architecture should integrate a dedicated domestic interface designed to present a comprehensive summary of all missed external information at the end of the day.

data.title: Branding identity presentation review
data.desc: The communication strategy requires substantial further development and must be strictly tailored to align with the chosen product approach.

data.title: Sheru visual identity after loss of organic elements
data.desc: The purely organic visual path was ultimately discarded because, beyond the physical product's limitations, the aesthetic failed to sustain the required provocation. Imagery associated with the sea and literal shells conveyed passivity and generic notions of wellbeing, directly undermining the brand's core assertive message of forced isolation and cognitive armor. The shift toward the mind and the cognitive sphere was subsequently initiated by adopting visual metaphors of structural and technological barriers. This involved integrating elements like the Turing pattern and generalized representations of the brain's structure onto the product’s surface (the headband) and throughout the visual identity. This approach uses aseptic precision and technological patterning to visually represent the internal, controlled defense mechanism of the mind, providing a functional, abstract visual language for the concept of psychological isolation.

data.title: Rethinking the speculation from the beginning
data.desc: The initial "What If" scenario is progressively losing its conceptual potency and relevance, weakening its connection to the final product output. It is therefore critical to revise the narrative framework to ensure the concept of isolation is rendered the central and most compelling theme.

data.title: Output shape simplification
data.desc: The decision was made to simplify the final output form to the maximum extent, marking a strategic pivot away from the shell-inspired helmet concept.

data.title: Definitive concept decision
data.desc:
The project's structural coherence is achieved by repositioning isolation as the central, proactive thesis—not a failure to cope, but the logical, evolutionary progression toward synthetic human improvement. Earlier attempts at passive, organic forms (the literal shell) and soft aesthetics were discarded as they failed to deliver the required provocation.

The final concept resolves this confusion by establishing a calculated philosophical framework: the mind achieves its apex state (Eden) only through complete, technological detachment. The physical product, a biotech-inspired training device (the cylinder/band), functions effectively by teaching social repulsion via conditioned sound reflexes, directly translating the philosophy into an active user experience. The overall system functions because the visual identity—characterized by aseptic coldness, Swiss Style rigor, and metallic transparency—perfectly mirrors this cold, calculated functional purpose, ensuring that the design's strict logic validates the logic of aggressive detachment. All elements, from the provocative E-DEN name to the repulsive training mechanism, synthesize into a single, cohesive message: Isolation is optimal control.

data.title: Final output
data.desc: The definitive final output is a simplified version of the full-face helmet concept. The chosen form is a cylinder featuring an opaque film band and internal bone transducers for sound conduction. The functionality is defined by contextual sound: the output is disturbing noise when near other individuals and calming noise when distant. Visually, the device incorporates metallic spikes and rods to communicate, in an even more evident manner, the user's repulsion toward others.

data.title: Output experience integration
data.desc: A mechanism for providing a synthesized post-session experience or retrospective data to the user is currently absent and must be integrated. This final feedback loop, delivered at the end of the day or use session, should effectively quantify the success of the intended isolation, potentially through metrics related to proximity avoidance or time effectively spent within the personal boundary.

data.title: Output - differentiation of sound and visual outputs
data.desc: The form of the output requires maximum simplification, prioritizing the interplay between positive and negative space rather than relying on highly literal representation. The dual core functionalities—utilizing the occluding film for one output and sound for the other—will be maintained. Concurrently, the design aesthetic must transition toward a substantially more generically technological form.

data.title: New helmet hypothesis and typography review
data.desc:
The brand identity needs custom typographic elements—ideally a bespoke font—to create a more organic character, as the current lilac color suggests skincare and is ineffective. One possible direction is to design letterforms inspired by frequency waves, potentially requiring hand-drawn development.
Visual identity and product design must evolve together. The product should feature interlocking components and emphasize negative space, using fabric with bone transducers and transparent areas that reveal internal parts. The form may resemble a shell or armor with varied 3D-printed textures, or alternatively shift toward a lighter, metallic aesthetic seen in the posters.
The user experience requires clear definition: how feedback is delivered, to whom, and how the experience ends. A detailed storyboard is needed, possibly concluding with a final audio message summarizing aggregated behavioral data.

data.title: Output design
data.desc: The literal interpretation of the shell form proves ultimately ineffective in conveying the desired provocation. Due to its intrinsic association with natural elements, passive protection, and gentle wellbeing, the literal shell aesthetic risks diluting the brand's core message by channeling connotations towards passivity and sustainability. The form lacks the necessary aggressive edge and technological assertiveness required to make a powerful statement about avoiding confrontation and forcing isolation. To achieve the intended provocation, the design must communicate an active, disruptive, and uncompromising barrier rather than a passive, organic retreat.

data.title: Company name decision
data.desc: The final decision retained the name e-den. This choice was purely strategic, as the name is used to generate conceptual provocation. By applying an extremely positive designation to a company fundamentally centered on the negative act of forced isolation and social repulsion, the juxtaposition creates a necessary friction and immediately highlights the brand's challenging philosophical stance. The name itself functions as a form of initial cognitive dissonance.

data.title: Sheru visual identity development
data.desc: Based on the observed difficulties in execution—particularly concerning applications, subject photography, and complex visual effects—the decision was made to halt the advanced visual development of the E-DEN aesthetic. The project will proceed by developing the SHERU identity further. However, the name E-DEN is retained as a source of conceptual provocation, leveraging an extremely positive designation for a fundamentally negative concept. The existing moodboard remains substantially unchanged, guiding the visual identity towards implementing the dual valence of technological and organic elements. There will be a definitive prevalence of the organic in the final visual execution because the structural, biological imagery is deemed more effective at immediately conveying the core concept of psychological armor and containment than a purely digital aesthetic.

data.title: Helmet output decision
data.desc: The strategic decision has been finalized to pursue the helmet form factor rather than a simplified earcuff or audio-only output. This choice is deemed the most sensible as the helmet provides the necessary physical dimension and communicative power to effectively embody the core concept of provocative isolation and complete external shielding. Its scale allows for the literal interpretation of a protective shell or armor, which is crucial for conveying the brand's assertive message against confrontation, unlike the more passive communication offered by smaller wearable accessories.

data.title: New identity trial poster applications
data.desc: The campaign concepts are unified by the idea of a provocative cognitive firewall, portraying external interaction and self-confrontation as painful states to be avoided. The visuals maintain an aseptic, high-contrast rigor, using embossed textures and blurred, plastic-like imagery to heighten tension. The messaging relies on unsettling, confrontational questions to present isolation as the only rational form of mental security. Metaphors range from abstract cognitive maps to primal symbols of retreat, like the Nautilus shell, and even visceral depictions of human discomfort. This multifaceted approach aggressively promotes self-protection, though it still risks missing the core conflict at the heart of the concept.

data.title: New teaser
data.desc: Production of the final teaser video: the opening scenes show blurred crowds, with a voice-over explaining the context of isolation, accompanied by subtitles. The audio tracks guide the understanding of the concept: the farther one is from people, the calmer the sound becomes.

data.title: Problems with Arduino and moving to Raspberry
data.desc:
During the ongoing development phase, work continued on the Arduino-based code. However, it was determined that the Arduino board's processing capacity was insufficient to simultaneously support the operation of four sensors while maintaining high-quality audio output.

Following a consultation with the project's code supervisor, the decision was made to migrate the system's hardware platform. The Arduino board was replaced with a Raspberry Pi 3B+ to meet the required computational and audio processing specifications.

Consequently, all software development has recommenced from the initial stage, utilizing a programming language appropriate for the new platform.
